definition: Eight Banners, military organization of Manchu later Jin dynasty 後金|后金[Hou4 Jin1] from c. 1600, subsequently of the Qing dynasty
eight/8
banner/flag/(in Qing times) Manchu (cf. 八旗[Ba1 qi2])/administrative subdivision in inner Mongolia equivalent to 縣|县[xian4] county/CL:面[mian4]
Eight Banners system, the military and social organization of the Manchus between c. 1500 and 1911
child of a Manchu bannerman family (nobility)/(fig.) privileged brat

sentences.english: The sources are a product of the Eight Banner registration system.
sentences.chinese: 這些資源是八旗戶籍制度的產物。

sentences.english: In the first year of Yongzheng, Qing government set up the military exam of Mongolian eight-counties.
sentences.chinese: 雍正元年，清政府開設了八旗蒙古武舉。

definition: Green standard army, standing infantry during Qing dynasty, originally formed from Ming and other Chinese army units
Manchurian soldier
Manchuria
Later Jin dynasty (from 1616-)/Manchu Khanate or kingdom that took over as Qing dynasty in 1644
Nurhaci (1559-1626), founder and first Khan of the Manchu Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金 (from 1616)
a Manchu
child of a Manchu bannerman family (nobility)/(fig.) privileged brat
Manchurian Qing (refers to the Qing dynasty, esp. at its decline, or as an anti-Qing slogan)
the Qing army
Dorgon (1612-1651), fourteenth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, successful general, instrumental in Manchu conquest of China, ruled China as regent 1644-1650 for his nephew Emperor Shunzhi 順治帝
Manchou township in Pingtung County 屏東縣|屏东县[Ping2 dong1 Xian4], Taiwan

Hong Taiji (1592-1643), eighth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, reigned 1626-1636 as Second Khan of Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金, then founded the Qing dynasty 大清 and reigned 1636-1643 as Emperor/posthumous name 清太宗
Jurchen, a Tungus ethnic group, predecessor of the Manchu ethnic group who founded the Later Jin Dynasty 後金|后金[Hou4 Jin1] and Qing Dynasty
Manchu/bannerman (refers to the eight Manchu banners 八旗[Ba1 qi2])
Manchurian foot soldier
